repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Agricultural Extension and
            Applied Research Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. There are several lessons to be
            learned: 1) In designing projects, the implementation
            environment (including macro-economic, political, sectoral
            factors) in a country for Bank assistance needs to be
            carefully reviewed as a whole to apply lessons learned. 2)
            Before introducing a system, implications of its costs on
            the state investment and recurrent cost budget needs to be
            analyzed. 3) Diversity of circumstances among beneficiaries
            and regions must be considered in the design; blanket
            prescriptions do not work. 4) Initiation of any second phase
            must depend on a thorough review of the ongoing project
            regarding implementation problems at the central and field
            level. 5) Solid monitoring data must be available to be able
            to make modifications during implementation. Therefore, a
            simple but effective monitoring and evaluation system needs
            to be established earlier in the project. 6) Strengthening
            of the beneficiaries position (farmers' organization)
            to formulate demand is needed to improve the performance of
            the organization.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Agricultural Extension and
            Applied Research Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project would be the second phase
            in a program to strengthen provincial extension services.
            The project would improve the implementation and management
            of provincial extension systems through diagnosing
            farmers' problems, decentralizing and mobilizing
            project staff, and providing training and strong technical
            support to field staff. To improve extension staff's
            contact with farmers, the project would provide housing in
            the villages, vehicles and equipment. It would provide
            additional specialist staff and training to widen the range
            of technical support given to field staff, and assist them
            in their work. The project would support research institutes
            and develop strong linkages between extension, research and
            farmers through diagnostic surveys. It would formulate
            responses to the needs of homogenous categories of farmers,
            monitor farmers' uptake and reactions to extension
            recommendations, and transfer research-based recommendations
            to reduce the degradation of Turkey's environment and
            agricultural resources. It would initiate a pilot program to
            train women engaged in agriculture, and a pilot program of
            mobile veterinary units to supply improved livestock health
            services in the villages. Finally, it would provide
            technical assistance to help implement the project, and
            funds to prepare a follow-up project.
